title: Every Day I Have the Blues

musicalLanguage.description: Originally by Memphis Slim, this became a hit for B.B. King in 1955. It is a perfect medium-tempo blues with a walking bass line and a singable melody. The walking left hand moves in steady quarter notes, creating a sense of forward motion like a slow train rolling.
musicalLanguage.structure: 12-bar blues with walking bass. This excerpt: first 8 bars
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: Bb7 — walking bass line starts its journey. Steady and relentless.
Bar 3-4: Bb7 — melody enters with a simple blues phrase
Bar 5-6: Eb7 — the IV chord. Walking bass adjusts to the new root.
Bar 7-8: Bb7 — home again. The bass never stops walking.
teachingGoals: Walking bass line — quarter note motion connecting chord tones
Coordinating walking bass with simple right-hand melody
Blues in Bb — a common key for blues and jazz
styleTips: Walking bass should be smooth and connected — legato quarter notes
The bass walks BETWEEN chord tones using scale and chromatic passing tones
Right hand stays simple — let the walking bass do the heavy lifting

measures.teachingNote: Bb7 — right hand arpeggiates up. Left hand walks: Bb-D-F-Ab (chord tones of Bb7).
Bb7 — the Db grace note is the blue 3rd. Left hand walks back down.
Bb7 — simple half notes in the melody. Left hand walks up chromatically: Bb-C-D-Eb.
Bb7 — melody rests. Left hand walks down with A as a chromatic approach to Bb.
Eb7 — IV chord! Walking bass shifts to Eb territory. Right hand arpeggiates Eb7.
Eb7 — melody descends. Left hand walks back down through Eb7 chord tones.
Bb7 — back to the tonic. The opening pattern returns.
Bb7 — descending to rest. Left hand mirrors the descent. Settling in.
